item.title: New Story - Tits for Tates
item.description: Coming very soon, a fun new story!

About Paige

I’m Paige Turner, and I write illustrated transgender fiction. I’ve been reading TG stories since the early 2000s—from alt.sex.stories to Nifty and Sapphire to Fictionmania and TGStorytime. These stories shaped my understanding of transformation narratives, and after years of reading, I recently decided to try creating the kind of fiction I always wanted to find more of.

I love slow builds where protagonists make reasonable decisions that accumulate into something irreversible, where they participate in their own transformation without realizing what’s coming until it’s too late. The loss of control, the moment of realization, the psychology of someone navigating an impossible situation—that’s what keeps me writing.

All my stories are available for free on Fictionmania and TG Storytime. Click through to read!

Highway to Elle

Tags: #MedTech #AgeRegression #Cheerleader

When star wide receiver Logan Turner suffers a devastating back injury that ends his football career and costs him his scholarship, desperation leads him to a mysterious facility promising athletic “repurposing” and a second chance. Under the care of the enigmatic Dr. Gupta, Logan begins a process he doesn’t fully understand—as strange occurrences mount at the facility, he faces a transformation far more profound than he ever anticipated, unaware that the path ahead is nothing like he could have imagined.

item.title: Best Friends Forever
item.description:
← Back to Stories

My third story, “Best Friends Forever"was an experiment: what happens if Paige is forced to write a story in 2 parts or less? After my first two stories ballooned way past their intended lengths, I was determined to stick to the limit here, as an exercise in developing my writing. The results were… mixed. Definitely the story that has gotten the most mixed feedback from readers, it is a tale that is both light and dark, and doesn’t really give the characters enough space to develop like they need to. But at the same time, I really love the transformation method, the images, and the mirrored structure of the first and last scenes.

item.title: Effortless Beauty
item.description:
← Back to Stories

After writing “Highway to Elle,” I needed a break from longer stories and wanted something fun, light, and–most importantly,–short. “Effortless Beauty” succeeded on 2 out of 3 - I wasn’t planning on it, but it ended up being a 4-part story of a mystical curse that slowly feminizes slovenly, lazy Sam every time he takes a shortcut.

Chapters:

  • Chapter 1 | Fictionmania | TG Storytime
  • Chapter 2 | Fictionmania | TG Storytime
  • Chapter 3 | Fictionmania | TG Storytime
  • Chapter 4 | Fictionmania | TG Storytime

item.title: Hex Lives of College Girls
item.description:
← Back to Stories

As luck would have it, I finished “Yvonne Girl” right before Halloween, and I was ready for a lighter, easier read. Halloween-themed transformation stories have always been a favorite of mine, so I was excited to participate in the tradition for the first time!

Chapters: Fictionmania TG Storytime Part 1 | TG Storytime Part 2

item.title: Highway to Elle
item.description:
← Back to Stories

Highway to Elle wasn’t just my first TG fiction story - it was my first attempt at writing fiction at all! Originally planned as a 3 or 4 chapter short story, it took on a life of its own and ended up at 16 chapters and an epilogue. Logan/Elle is still the character I’m most fond of, and the one I like to imagine having a full life after the end of the story.

item.title: Yvonne Girl
item.description:
← Back to Stories

My fourth story and second novel-length work, “Yvonne Girl” was borne out of my love for TG fiction stories about an escalating power struggle, with both parties too stubborn to back down until someone goes over the brink. Inspired by StacyInLove’s “Don’t Blink” and MelissaN’s “Tug of War,” I knew I wanted to blend those transgender fiction themes with a political thriller. Yvonne combines the cynical power dynamics of Robert Penn Warren’s All the King’s Men, the intimate political character work of Billy Lee Brammer’s The Gay Place, and the psychological manipulation of Gillian Flynn’s Gone Girl. The question that drove me was: what if someone’s greatest character flaw wasn’t a moral failing, but the desperate need to matter? And what if someone brilliant enough saw that flaw and knew exactly how to exploit it?

item.title: Halloween Story!
item.description: It’s my first Halloween since I started writing fiction, so of course I was going to try my hand at the classic costume-gone-wrong tale.

item.title: Time for a Site Relaunch Already?
item.description: Guess we’re going to find out if I really know what I’m doing.
